section.title: Preface
section.para: LightCouch provides a Java persistence interface for CouchDB databases, it defines a set of APIs for communicating with the RESTful JSON APIs provided by CouchDB.
Through it's API, LightCouch offers a simple yet powerful persistence interface, that is easy-to-use and lightweight.
LightCouch APIs was designed to offer a high degree of reliability and flexibility, with minimal code base and dependency.

section.title: Overview
section.para: LightCouch API is presented by establishing a client to a database server instance.
A LightCouch client is the central and primary gate way for gaining access to all of the available APIs.
The API in LightCouch is organized and grouped by functionality under different contexts, that is accessible via a client instance.

The API is mainly focused on document persistence, supporting CRUD (i.e Create Read Update Delete) kind of operations. Another set of APIs for handling CouchDB Views and Design documents, and another for performing database specific tasks such as database replication and compaction.
Note: The API is covered by an integration unit tests packaged with the source code, see Download. The API was tested against CouchDB up to version 1.1.1

section.title: Setup
section.para: To setup LightCouch for use in your application, you need to have the binary distribution (along with it's dependencies) available to your application classpath. Maven users could add the LightCouch dependency element to their application pom.xml file:
section.programlisting: <dependency> <groupId>org.lightcouch</groupId> <artifactId>lightcouch</artifactId> <version>0.0.4</version> </dependency>

section.title: Configuration
section.para: To configure a LightCouch client, you may use a .properties file containing all the parameters required to successfully connect to a running database instance.

Typically prepare a file named couchdb.properties and make it available to your application default classpath. A client knows how to find and parse this file to extract all the necessary parameters it needs:
section.programlisting:
### Required couchdb.name=db-test couchdb.createdb.if-not-exist=true # The protocol: http | https couchdb.protocol=http couchdb.host=127.0.0.1 # The port e.g: 5984 | 6984 couchdb.port=5984 # Blank username/password for no login couchdb.username= couchdb.password=
### Optional/Advanced # Timeout to wait for a response, in milliseconds. Defaults to 0 (no timeout). couchdb.http.socket.timeout= # Timeout to establish a connection, in milliseconds. Defaults to 0 (no timeout). couchdb.http.connection.timeout=

section.title: Using LightCouch
section.para: As mentioned earlier, you have to create a client to start using the API.

A client class is called org.lightcouch.CouchDbClient. It offers three convenient constructors for instantiating a new instance, or multiple instances if you wish to handle multiple databases simultaneously, typically each client handles one database, in isolation.
The easiest way to instantiate a new client is by using it's default constructor, it will search your application default classpath for the file you have created earlier, i.e couchdb.properties
section.programlisting: CouchDbClient dbClient = new CouchDbClient(); // API is ready to use
section.para: Another overloaded constructor accepts a properties file name to be supplied:
section.programlisting: CouchDbClient dbClient2 = new CouchDbClient("couchdb-2.properties");
section.para: The final constructor accepts individual parameters to be supplied directly, may be useful when using external files does not make sence in your environment, or for dynamic creation of a client on the fly:
section.programlisting: CouchDbClient dbClient3 = new CouchDbClient(...);
section.para: Note: A client instance is thread-safe, typically you would create one at the beginning of your application startup and re-use it throughout your code.
At the end of usage, it might be useful to shutdown a client's underlying connection manager, and thus ensure a proper release of resources:
section.programlisting: dbClient.shutdown();

section.title: Spring Integration
section.para: If you use Spring in your environment, it may be useful to define LightCouch clients as Spring beans, and let Spring DI container handles initializing and injecting your client(s):
section.programlisting: <bean id="dbClient" class="org.couchy.CouchDbClient" destroy-method="shutdown"/> <bean id="dbClient2" class="org.lightcouch.CouchDbClient" destroy-method="shutdown"> <constructor-arg value="couchdb-2.properties" /> </bean>
section.para: Autowire a client to your Spring components:
section.programlisting: @Autowired private CouchDbClient dbClient;

section.title: Documents API
section.para: Document persistence API is accessible under a client instance directly. A LightCouch client acts as an EntityManager that is used in JPA, it provides convenient methods for handling document persistence.
The API supports CRUD operations to be performed on documents.
Documents in a CouchDB are mainly identified by declaring two fields, an id and a revision (i.e _id and _rev).
Your model data is required to declare those special fields to qualify as valid persisted documents.

LightCouch provides a convenient base class which you may choose to extend by your model classes, this class is called org.lightcouch.Document. If it's not your flavor, or if you want your objects not to depend on LightCouch (this may be preferable as to promote models portability across different domains), you may use JSON mapping annotations (i.e com.google.gson.annotations.SerializedName("_id") for example), or, to get away with clean models, you may define those special fields by their naming convention (i.e String _id & String _rev).
LightCouch gives you the flexibility of choosing a model data most suitable to your application, you may choose to work with raw streams, JSON objects, Maps, and rich domain models.
LightCouch has a dependency on Google Gson library which it relies on for handling JSON/Java mapping. During serialization Gson by default will not serialize null fields.
The following sections explores what LightCouch API offers for handling document persistence.

section.title: Saving/Updating Documents
section.para:
Documents could be saved and updated by using methods conventiently named save() and update() both methods takes an entity object as parameter.
An object may be one of: 1. A plain Java object (POJO). 2. A java.util.Map holding key/value pairs. 3. A com.google.gson.JsonObject object, which is a JSON representation class from Gson.
When saving a new object, it worth to mention that LightCouch will generate an UUID for your object _id field before sending it over to the database, but only in case you left it blank.
Beside the usual saving operation, you may also use batch(), which may be suitable for logging scenarios.

Normally when you persist an object to CouchDB, the database replies with the document Id and revision, a Response object holds this information.

section.title: Finding Documents
section.para:
Retrieving documents API is offered by a convenient method find(), it accepts a document id and or revision.
As a return type, you may choose one of: 1. An InputStream. 2. A com.google.gson.JsonObject object. 3. A plain Java object.
A java.util.Map however does not qualify for a return type.

An additional finder method findAny() is provided as to give more control over the query, typically use it to retrieve any kind of document when there is no equivalent API already supported by the client. Unlike other finder methods, this method expects a fully formatted and encoded URI to be supplied.
When working with streams, it is important to close it after usage to release the connection.

section.title: Attachments API
section.para: Documents in CouchDB may have attachments, either inline or standalone. The following sections illustrates both features.

section.title: Inline Attachments
section.para: To save an inline attachment, the class org.lightcouch.Attachment exposes properties for setting a base64 encoded string, and a content type of the attachment. A document may have one or more inline attachments which get saved along with the enclosing document during the usual save operation described above.
To enable inline attachments in a domain model, one may extend org.lightcouch.Document which provides means for adding attachments, or if a domain does not extend Document, see the example below.
Retrieving a document that has an attachment does not also retrieve the attachment itself, instead it returns metadata.
Note: For encoding base64 strings, Base64.encodeBase64String(bytes) may be used, thats included in Apache Codec.

section.para: Standalone attachments may be saved to an existing, or to a new document. The supporting method expects an attachment in an InputStream format holding binary data, and a "Content-Type" to be provided. The corresponding APIs for saving attachments is available under a client instance.

section.title: Logging and Error Handling
section.para: Logging may be useful during development, LightCouch is designed to provide concise logging messages and report errors as you work with the API.

section.title: Logging
section.para: By enabling a more verbose logging level (i.e INFO for example), LightCouch will log events as they occure. You can get hold of useful information during development like what API calls is made, how a request URI and parameters look like, and what reply the database has responsed as a result to your request.
If you are using Log4j in your application, you may control logging levels like this:
section.programlisting: # Controls LightCouch logging log4j.logger.org.lightcouch=INFO # Controls Apache HttpClient logging log4j.logger.org.apache.http=ERROR

section.title: Error Handling
section.para: In the event of failure, the API will throw specific exceptions in correspondence to the failed event, by proper handling from your application side, you can take the appropriate decision based on the exception that is being thrown.

LightCouch provides three convenient runtime exception classes for that purpose.
1. NoDocumentException when a requested document could not be found (or a view with no result). 2. DocumentConflictException when a conflict is detected during a save or update. 3. CouchDbException is the super class for the former two exception classes, for bravity, it is thrown in every other failure events, i.e in cases of HTTP error (400) for instance.

section.title: Views API
section.para: The API for CouchDB views is accessible via a client instance under a special context view(String) which accepts a view name, consisting of the design document name and the view name (i.e example/foo for example) this results in requesting a view with the full URI of _design/example/_view/foo

The API employs a Builder pattern for constructing views query requests by chaining the appropriate parameters that makes sence for a specific view. Query a view given a Complex key is tightly integrated in the API.

Views query is supported by a number of options you may choose from, as per a use case:
1. List<T> A list of a specified type. 2. InputStream raw streaming. 3. Scalar values (i.e int etc.) 4. View entries (keys/values) as they reside in the database B-Tree. 5. Pagination.

section.title: Design Documents
section.para: The API for Design documents is accessible via a client instance under yet another special context design().

Design documents may be edited and saved on text .js files and then pushed to the database, an approach implemented by couchapp. If you have downloaded LightCouch source code, you can see a working example in the test package.
Design documents may be maintained on disk files and saved on your application classpath, with the following directory structure:
section.programlisting: design-docs |- example |- filters |- filter1.js |- filter2.js |- .. |- lists |- list1.js |- list2.js |- shows |- show1.js |- show2.js |- validate_doc_update |- validate.js |- views |- by_date |- map.js |- by_tag |- map.js |- reduce.js |- example2 ...
section.para: Usage Example:

You may refer to the Javadocs to see all supported operations: org.lightcouch.CouchDbDesign A DesignDocument object that is used to carry a design document, properly implements equals(). This may come in handy for comparing documents that are loaded from either desk files or the database, this is what practically is used when synchronizeWithDb() is invoked, as to avoid un-necessary updates to a design document in the database that is up-to-date.

section.title: Replication
section.para: LightCouch provides two subset of APIs for handling database replication, it supports the traditional replication that is issued by POSTing to _replicate URI, and the newer replicator database (i.e _replicator by default) that is introduced with CouchDB version 1.1.0 A replication request is triggered by saving a document in the replicator database, and is canceled by removing the document that triggered the replication.
